snippet: High-end shopping malls are thriving across the country, but as midtier retailers like Sears and J. C. Penney flounder, they are also dragging down their malls.
abstract: Sixty shopping malls catering to middle- and working-class shoppers are on brink of closure due to failing fortunes of retail chains like J C Penney, Sears and Kmart; Owing Mills Mall in Maryland is one of these malls, and experts say that enclosed malls are closing due to boom in retail space construction that has led to glut of stores; so-called dead malls inspire in some customers dismay, and in others feelings of nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: High-end shopping malls are thriving across the country, but as midtier retailers like Sears and J. C. Penney flounder, they are also dragging down their malls.

headline.main: The Economics (and Nostalgia) of Dead Malls
headline.print_headline: The Economics (and Nostalgia) of Dead Malls
